quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 11: Unit 8 Quiz 1
quiz.subtitle: 8.1: Properties of Gases and Pressure Measurements
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Fundamental gas properties and pressure units

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic property of gases compared to liquids and solids?
questions.explanation: Because gas molecules are separated by large amounts of empty space, they can be easily squeezed into smaller volumes.

questions.question: Pressure is mathematically defined as:
options: Force multiplied by Distance ($P = F \cdot d$)
questions.explanation: Gas pressure is the result of countless collisions of gas particles against the walls of their container over a specific area.

questions.question: What is the standard atmospheric pressure at sea level in millimeters of mercury (mmHg)?
questions.explanation: Standard pressure is defined as $760$ mmHg, which is also equal to $1$ atm or $760$ torr.

questions.question: Which device is specifically used to measure the pressure of the atmosphere?
questions.explanation: Evangelista Torricelli invented the mercury barometer to measure the 'weight' of the air pressing down on Earth.

questions.question: Convert $2.0$ atm of pressure into kilopascals (kPa). (Standard pressure $= 101.325$ kPa)
A manometer is used to measure:
options: The pressure of a gas trapped in a container
The volume of a gas at STP
questions.explanation: While barometers measure atmospheric pressure, manometers measure the pressure of a specific sample relative to the atmosphere or a vacuum.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the behavior of gases where they move to fill their entire container regardless of its shape?
questions.explanation: Gases do not have a definite shape or volume; they expand spontaneously to fill whatever space is available.

questions.question: Which set of conditions is known as Standard Temperature and Pressure (STP)?
questions.explanation: STP is used as a reference point: $273.15$ K ($0$째C) and $1$ atm ($101.325$ kPa).

questions.question: If the pressure of a gas is $380$ torr, what is this pressure in atmospheres (atm)?
What happens to the pressure of a gas if the frequency and force of molecular collisions with the container walls increase?
questions.explanation: Pressure is the macroscopic measurement of these microscopic collisions.

scoreMessages.90: Great start! You're under no pressure at all with these units.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. You're getting comfortable with pressure conversions.
scoreMessages.50: Good effort. Make sure to memorize the relationship: $1\text{ atm} = 760\text{ mmHg} = 101.3\text{ kPa}$.
